description: Betty was born Elizabeth Ann Bingham to St. John Bingham and Annis Morison Bingham in Bristol, Tenn., on August 8, 1940. She spent part of her childhood in Bristol. After her mother's death, Betty returned to Bristol to live with her grandmother Elizabeth Turner Morison and graduated from Tennessee High School in 1958.
text:
Elizabeth Bingham Marney died peacefully and unexpectedly at home on May 26,
2020. Betty was born Elizabeth Ann Bingham to St. John Bingham and Annis
Morison Bingham in Bristol, Tenn., on August 8, 1940. She spent part of her
childhood in Bristol. Although an only child, she adored trips to the lake and
a great deal of mischief with the cousins whom she considered sisters. She
moved to the Panama Canal Zone with her mother when she was 10. After her
mother's death, Betty returned to Bristol to live with her grandmother
Elizabeth Turner Morison and graduated from Tennessee High School in 1958. She
completed an AA degree at Sullins College before matriculating to the
University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill where she earned a BA and MA in
English, graduating Summa Cum Laude. She was a member of the Phi Beta Kappa
Society and was known to wear her PBK key in the same way Madeleine Albright
wears brooches. If she had the key on, she was planning to win. After
graduating from UNC, she took a teaching position at Southern Methodist
University in 1963 where she worked with Laurence "Larry" Perrine, the author
of Literature, Structure, Sound, and Sense: a title that will evoke memories
for all Harpeth Hall Students who crossed paths with Betty from 1975-1985. And
although she did leave UNC physically, she remained a tried and true Tarheel
for life!!! After SMU, Betty attended the University of Texas at Austin where
she earned her PhD in English and wrote her dissertation on Saul Bellow. On
one of her trips back home to Bristol, Betty's grandmother set her up on a
blind date with a promising young medical resident, albeit from the Va. side
of Bristol, named Sam Marney. After the first date, Betty's Grandmother asked,
"Well, what did you talk about?' Betty said, "Politics." Her grandmother
replied, "Betty, you fool!" After a brief a courtship, Sam proposed, and Betty
told him, "Well, I'll think about it." She soon acquiesced and Betty and Sam
celebrated 53 years of marriage on October 1, 2019. Betty and Sam lived in
Nashville for most of their married life with the exception of a year in
Oxford, England, in 1967-68 where they made lifelong friends and delivered
their son Sam. Their daughter Annis was born in Nashville in 1970 and the
entire Marney clan went on a year-long adventure to California where Sam
conducted research at Scripps in La Jolla. They returned to Nashville in 1974
and stayed put. Betty embarked on a teaching career at Harpeth Hall School in
1975, where for 10 years she earned a reputation as both inspiring and
sometimes terrifying. Her love of English literature was contagious. She
adored working with young women, and she helped establish some traditions that
became lore, including dressing up with colleagues Dona Gower and Sarah Stamps
as the Three Witches from Macbeth for Halloween. Although students sometimes
(often) confessed to living in fear of Betty, she was also called by many
students the best teacher they had ever encountered. Over their working lives,
Betty and Sam and their children enjoyed being frequent guests of their dear
friends Dona and Herschel Gower, and their daughter Alison at Beersheba
Springs, Tenn., where they hiked and swam and looked out on the valley from
the deck. The children learned a great deal about whether Billy Budd was a
travesty or a tragedy when the "Big Dipper Poured." Dona and Betty disagreed,
amicably. On many Thanksgivings, Dona and others would cook, and Betty would
"supervise." Betty and Sam also enjoyed many weekends as guests on the other
side of Monteagle Mountain with their dear friends David and Kay Hall at
Sewanee. Speed sitting on that deck was delightful. Being up on the cool
plateau suited Betty's inner temperature (too hot). After leaving Harpeth Hall
in 1985, Betty earned a law degree from Vanderbilt at the age of 48. She had
come from a line of attorneys, judges, and the occasional criminal and thrived
in her second career as a lawyer. She began with first amendment work at King
and Ballow before becoming in-house counsel at the Nashville Banner newspaper,
and she was proud to have written the brief and been in attendance in one case
before the U.S. Supreme Court. She completed her legal career working in the
Criminal Appellate Division of the Tennessee Attorney General's office where
friends may not be surprised to learn that she enjoyed being called "General."
Upon leaving her legal office at the state for the last time in 2008, and not
being terribly sentimental, she had no desire to hang her law degree on her
wall at home, so she put it in the trash. It was then collected by a colleague
who had always wanted a Vanderbilt law degree, and as far as we know it still
hangs in someone's office in the Tennessee AG's office. Upon retirement in
2008, Betty and Sam enjoyed several years of international travel. With the
exception of Antarctica, they visited every continent, making friends and
building memories. You haven't really seen a picture of Betty until you've
seen her riding a camel. She and Sam enjoyed their grandchildren, who called
them GrandBetty and GrandSam. She took great pride in her grandchildren's many
and varied accomplishments. Being the consummate teacher, she also took every
opportunity to teach them about whatever might interest them. She remained an
avid reader all her life, and sharing and talking about books was a favorite
pastime. After travel was no longer possible, she and Sam enjoyed a quiet
routine at home, reading the New Yorker weekly, the New York Times daily,
staying up to date on current politics, and worrying about the country going
to hell in a handbasket. The past few years, Betty served as a steadfast and
loving companion for her husband, Sam, who has suffered from various
illnesses. Recently, she expressed profound gratitude for the many generous
and kind caregivers who have helped her and Sam so they could stay in their
home in Green Hills, where they lived for over 50 years. She is survived by
her husband, Samuel Rowe Marney Jr.; her son, Samuel Rowe Marney III of
Memphis; his daughters, Dylan Elizabeth Marney and Quinn Alexis Marney; and
their mother, Tara Gruet Marney; her daughter, Annis Morison Marney and her
husband, Glenn Gustus Dukes, Jr., and their children, Ian Marney Dukes and
Annis Kyle (AK) Morison Dukes; and her sister-in-law, Nancy Marney. A small,
private funeral service was held at home on Saturday, May 30, 2020, with
Pastor Carol Cavin-Dillon of West End United Methodist Church. Carol once was
a student of Betty's, which would have pleased Betty enormously. Turns out
Carol attended Duke University, but we still think very highly of her. The
family hopes to host a celebration of Betty's life later this summer. Memorial
gifts may be made to the Beersheba Springs Medical Clinic online at
<https://beershebaclinic.org/donate/> or by mail, P.O. Box 112, Beersheba
Springs, TN 37305.

title: Marney, Elizabeth Bingham
html: Elizabeth Bingham Marney died peacefully and unexpectedly at home on May 26, 2020. Betty was born Elizabeth Ann Bingham to St. John Bingham and Annis Morison Bingham in Bristol, Tenn., on August 8, 1940. She spent part of her childhood in Bristol. Although an only child, she adored trips to the lake and a great deal of mischief with the cousins whom she considered sisters. She moved to the Panama Canal Zone with her mother when she was 10. After her mother's death, Betty returned to Bristol to live with her grandmother Elizabeth Turner Morison and graduated from Tennessee High School in 1958. She completed an AA degree at Sullins College before matriculating to the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill where she earned a BA and MA in English, graduating Summa Cum Laude. She was a member of the Phi Beta Kappa Society and was known to wear her PBK key in the same way Madeleine Albright wears brooches. If she had the key on, she was planning to win. After graduating from UNC, she took a teaching position at Southern Methodist University in 1963 where she worked with Laurence "Larry" Perrine, the author of Literature, Structure, Sound, and Sense: a title that will evoke memories for all Harpeth Hall Students who crossed paths with Betty from 1975-1985. And although she did leave UNC physically, she remained a tried and true Tarheel for life!!! After SMU, Betty attended the University of Texas at Austin where she earned her PhD in English and wrote her dissertation on Saul Bellow. On one of her trips back home to Bristol, Betty's grandmother set her up on a blind date with a promising young medical resident, albeit from the Va. side of Bristol, named Sam Marney. After the first date, Betty's Grandmother asked, "Well, what did you talk about?' Betty said, "Politics." Her grandmother replied, "Betty, you fool!" After a brief a courtship, Sam proposed, and Betty told him, "Well, I'll think about it." She soon acquiesced and Betty and Sam celebrated 53 years of marriage on October 1, 2019. Betty and Sam lived in Nashville for most of their married life with the exception of a year in Oxford, England, in 1967-68 where they made lifelong friends and delivered their son Sam. Their daughter Annis was born in Nashville in 1970 and the entire Marney clan went on a year-long adventure to California where Sam conducted research at Scripps in La Jolla. They returned to Nashville in 1974 and stayed put. Betty embarked on a teaching career at Harpeth Hall School in 1975, where for 10 years she earned a reputation as both inspiring and sometimes terrifying. Her love of English literature was contagious. She adored working with young women, and she helped establish some traditions that became lore, including dressing up with colleagues Dona Gower and Sarah Stamps as the Three Witches from Macbeth for Halloween. Although students sometimes (often) confessed to living in fear of Betty, she was also called by many students the best teacher they had ever encountered. Over their working lives, Betty and Sam and their children enjoyed being frequent guests of their dear friends Dona and Herschel Gower, and their daughter Alison at Beersheba Springs, Tenn., where they hiked and swam and looked out on the valley from the deck. The children learned a great deal about whether Billy Budd was a travesty or a tragedy when the "Big Dipper Poured." Dona and Betty disagreed, amicably. On many Thanksgivings, Dona and others would cook, and Betty would "supervise." Betty and Sam also enjoyed many weekends as guests on the other side of Monteagle Mountain with their dear friends David and Kay Hall at Sewanee. Speed sitting on that deck was delightful. Being up on the cool plateau suited Betty's inner temperature (too hot). After leaving Harpeth Hall in 1985, Betty earned a law degree from Vanderbilt at the age of 48. She had come from a line of attorneys, judges, and the occasional criminal and thrived in her second career as a lawyer. She began with first amendment work at King and Ballow before becoming in-house counsel at the Nashville Banner newspaper, and she was proud to have written the brief and been in attendance in one case before the U.S. Supreme Court. She completed her legal career working in the Criminal Appellate Division of the Tennessee Attorney General's office where friends may not be surprised to learn that she enjoyed being called "General." Upon leaving her legal office at the state for the last time in 2008, and not being terribly sentimental, she had no desire to hang her law degree on her wall at home, so she put it in the trash. It was then collected by a colleague who had always wanted a Vanderbilt law degree, and as far as we know it still hangs in someone's office in the Tennessee AG's office. Upon retirement in 2008, Betty and Sam enjoyed several years of international travel. With the exception of Antarctica, they visited every continent, making friends and building memories. You haven't really seen a picture of Betty until you've seen her riding a camel. She and Sam enjoyed their grandchildren, who called them GrandBetty and GrandSam. She took great pride in her grandchildren's many and varied accomplishments. Being the consummate teacher, she also took every opportunity to teach them about whatever might interest them. She remained an avid reader all her life, and sharing and talking about books was a favorite pastime. After travel was no longer possible, she and Sam enjoyed a quiet routine at home, reading the New Yorker weekly, the New York Times daily, staying up to date on current politics, and worrying about the country going to hell in a handbasket. The past few years, Betty served as a steadfast and loving companion for her husband, Sam, who has suffered from various illnesses. Recently, she expressed profound gratitude for the many generous and kind caregivers who have helped her and Sam so they could stay in their home in Green Hills, where they lived for over 50 years. She is survived by her husband, Samuel Rowe Marney Jr.; her son, Samuel Rowe Marney III of Memphis; his daughters, Dylan Elizabeth Marney and Quinn Alexis Marney; and their mother, Tara Gruet Marney; her daughter, Annis Morison Marney and her husband, Glenn Gustus Dukes, Jr., and their children, Ian Marney Dukes and Annis Kyle (AK) Morison Dukes; and her sister-in-law, Nancy Marney. A small, private funeral service was held at home on Saturday, May 30, 2020, with Pastor Carol Cavin-Dillon of West End United Methodist Church. Carol once was a student of Betty's, which would have pleased Betty enormously. Turns out Carol attended Duke University, but we still think very highly of her. The family hopes to host a celebration of Betty's life later this summer. Memorial gifts may be made to the Beersheba Springs Medical Clinic online at https://beershebaclinic.org/donate/ or by mail, P.O. Box 112, Beersheba Springs, TN 37305.
